column3: he was a free agent signing by the Bucs (from the Jets) and dislocated his ankle in Week 1. That’s the same ugly injury Chris Godwin had. column5: was once the Jets’ No. 1 corner in 2021 but stud the team adding Sauce Gardner and D.J. Reed knocked him out of their starting lineup. He’s got 26 career starts under his belt. column2: the Bucs may not very good at that
column3: but the modern game demands dangerous edge rushers. It’s easy to argue it’s the most important position on a defense. That’s why they’re paid so much damn money. The Bucs just signed beastly edge rusher Haason Reddick
column4: who had a ghastly 2024 but is loaded with talent and stud seasons on his resume at 30 years old. They also have YaYa Diaby
column5: a third-year edge rusher with elite talent
column6: but his game has proven to be incomplete. There’s veteran Anthony Nelson in the stable
column7: a solid backup but not a dangerous edge rusher. And they’ve got second-year man Chris Braswell. On the Ira Kaufman Podcast
column8: Buccaneers Ring of Honor general manager Jason Licht said he’s confident Braswell with “shock” fans this season. So do the Bucs think they’re set at edge rusher? Former Eagles
column9: Browns and Ravens scout Daniel Jeremiah
column11: doesn’t think so. The NFL Network draft guru believes the Bucs will go edge rusher in Round 1 at pick No. 19
column12: per his latest mock draft. He’s got the Bucs taking Donovan Ezeiruaku out of Boston Collee. “Bucs GM Jason Licht has always valued production
column13: and Ezeiruaku brings exactly that to the table with 16.5 sacks last season. He’s one of the most gifted pass rushers in the draft

column16: Joe would applaud drafting Ezeiruaku. Hey
column17: the Rams are ecstatic after drafting defensive rookie of the year Jared Verse at No. 19 last season. The next edge rusher off the board
column19: had a very strong season finish for the Dolphins (6 sacks in his final 10 games). Yes
column20: first-round rookie edge rushers sometimes make an impact late in their rookie years. (The other three edge rushers taken in last year’s first round did not have special seasons). At 6-2
column22: Ezeiruaku is a small edge rusher
column23: but he’s got superior athleticism (a former track star) and Joe likes that he’s still just 21 years old. The former Boston College captain surely will add man strength and weight next season. If the Bucs think he’s the best available player on the board

column4: but he made it clear it was in February. (The following is David’s verbatim response

column2: Lavonte David Made His Case For The Pro Football Hall Of Fame|It really grinds Joe’s gears the way Lavonte David is shat on each and every year. Joe doesn’t give a rat’s rear end about the Pro Bowl but the guys and gals who vote on the Pro Football Hall of Fame value that dumbass game and use it to push for or run off Hall candidates. It’s an outage this is a criterion
column3: but it is. And it’s a reason Joe gets steamed every year that David doesn’t get named to that waste of time and energy. Joe has maintained for years there is no more disrespected player in the league than David. Hell
column4: he’s fifth in NFL history (since the NFL began keeping track of solo tackles in 1994) in most career solo tackles. And the guy can’t sniff the friggin’ Pro Bowl and never gets any run when Hall of Fame players come up. Criminal! Now yesterday at One Buc Palace
column5: David was not asked about the Hall of Fame. He was asked how playing linebacker in the NFL has changed since he was drafted in 2012. David’s response was a helluva pitch for him being in the Pro Football Hall of Fame someday. “That’s something that I just started thinking about
column6: ” David said. “Somebody in my position playing inside linebacker who basically has to be the leader of the defense – the quarterback of the defense. “In my 14 years of playing
column7: I’ve probably played with five defensive coordinators. [Joe’s note: Actually six.] Each defense
column8: I adapted to it and I made it what’s good for me – I prevailed in each one. So
column10: taking what I learned from those defenses
column11: and putting it into my game right now. “The game doesn’t change
column12: people do the same thing but in different ways. Once you learn that and try to adjust to that
column13: the game just slows down to you. It’s just fun to see all of that just come together – all of the things that you learn from your rookie year all the way until now and putting it into fruition and watch yourself and see your product on the field
column14: how you’re moving through stuff like that and how you adapt to the game the way it’s played now. It’s a great feeling for you
column15: personally.” And there you have it. It doesn’t matter if David played for Bill Sheridan or Leslie Frazier or lousy Lovie Smith or Mike Smith or Mark Duffner or Todd Bowles
column19: and played elite football game in and game out for 13 years. All the while being a total class act. If that’s not a Hall of Fame player
column20: then Joe doesn’t know what one looks like.|2025-03-18 07:00:00|458|26|5|Lavonte David|David's case for Pro Football Hall of Fame.|8|Supportive and optimistic sentiments towards Lavonte David's Hall of Fame induction chances.|"{""commenter0"": {""username"": ""lambchop""

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/being-proactive-has-helped-lavonte-david-stay-on-the-field-and-stay-with-the-bucs/|Being Proactive Has Helped Lavonte David Stay On The Field And Stick With The Bucs|There may be a lesson here for a couple of other Bucs defenders. For Lavonte David
column3: to be entering his 14th season as one of the premier linebackers in the game
column4: he first has to have good genes. David was asked yesterday at One Buc Palace what he does to keep himself physically healthy. Very rarely do you see David miss consecutive games. David said the trick for him is being proactive
column5: no matter how small a bump or bruise may be. “I think the main thing for me is just taking care of things while it’s a little problem
column6: before making it a big problem
column7: ” David said. Any time I feel any nicks or bumps
column9: I try to get on top of it really fast so it doesn’t become a big problem. “Then
column10: getting my conditioning level to where it needs to be and taking care of my body right away – eating right
column11: doing what I’m supposed to be doing
column12: being disciplined in all aspects. “I just feel like the off the field life when you’re disciplined
column13: it [carries] over to the on the field life.” Joe took that last sentence to suggest that hitting the clubs today means hitting the unemployment line tomorrow. Joe has heard more and more the past few years about how diets have helped players gain longevity. We all know Tom Brady
column15: was famously strict about his diet. You know
column16: the famed avocado ice cream? (Anyone remember how Josh Freeman bragged he stopped at Taco Bell every day after practice? Then again
column17: his problem wasn’t physical. His problem was between his ears.) Once upon a time players just gutted it out. As long as you were walking
column18: you were fine and only the weaklings and attention hogs ran to the doctor. Now
column19: with sports science and modern medicine
column20: only the dumbarses try to act like the tough guy.
